Reply:
– Polizei-Ministerin Bheki Cele

# Südafrika: Menschenhandel wird von Ausländern betrieben

Südafrikas Polizei-Ministerin Bheki Cele hat erklärt, dass die Mehrheit der Menschenhändler in Südafrika aus dem Ausland stammt. Cele sagte, dass die südafrikanische Polizei (SAPS) in den letzten Jahren große Fortschritte bei der Bekämpfung des Menschenhandels gemacht habe, aber dass die Täter oft aus anderen Ländern stammen.

„Sie sind ein Experte darin. Der Menschenhandel in Südafrika wird von Ausländern betrieben“, sagte Cele während einer Pressekonferenz in Pretoria. „Sie kommen hierher, weil sie wissen, dass wir ein weiches Ziel sind.“

Cele sagte, dass die SAPS in den letzten Jahren mehr als 1.000 Fälle von Menschenhandel untersucht habe und dass viele der Täter aus Ländern wie Nigeria, China und Bangladesch stammen. Er fügte hinzu, dass die Polizei eng mit anderen Strafverfolgungsbehörden in der Region zusammenarbeitet, um den Menschenhandel zu bekämpfen.

Der Menschenhandel ist ein weltweites Problem, das Millionen von Menschen betrifft. Die Vereinten Nationen schätzen, dass jedes Jahr etwa 25 Millionen Menschen Opfer von Menschenhandel werden. In Südafrika ist der Menschenhandel besonders besorgniserregend, da das Land ein wichtiges Transit- und Zielgebiet für Menschenhändler ist.

Die Regierung hat in den letzten Jahren Maßnahmen ergriffen, um den Menschenhandel zu bekämpfen, darunter die Verabschiedung des Prevention and Combating of Trafficking in Persons Act im Jahr 2013. Trotzdem bleibt der Menschenhandel ein großes Problem in Südafrika, und die Polizei kämpft darum, die Täter zur Rechenschaft zu ziehen.

Cele forderte die Öffentlichkeit auf, wachsam zu sein und verdächtige Aktivitäten zu melden. „Wir können dieses Problem nicht alleine lösen. Wir brauchen die Hilfe der Gemeinschaft“, sagte er. „Wenn Sie etwas Verdächtiges sehen, melden Sie es der Polizei.“

Die Bekämpfung des Menschenhandels erfordert eine gemeinsame Anstrengung von Regierung, Strafverfolgungsbehörden und der Öffentlichkeit. Während die Polizei Fortschritte bei der Bekämpfung des Menschenhandels macht, bleibt noch viel zu tun, um dieses schreckliche Verbrechen zu stoppen.

# South Africa: Human trafficking is carried out by foreigners

South Africa's Police Minister Bheki Cele has stated that the majority of human traffickers in South Africa are foreign nationals. Cele said that the South African Police Service (SAPS) has made great strides in combating human trafficking in recent years, but that the perpetrators often come from other countries.

"They are an expert at it. Human trafficking in South Africa is done by foreigners," Cele said during a press conference in Pretoria. "They come here because they know we are a soft target."

Cele said the SAPS had investigated more than 1 000 cases of human trafficking in recent years and that many of the perpetrators came from countries such as Nigeria, China and Bangladesh. He added that the police were working closely with other law enforcement agencies in the region to combat human trafficking.

Human trafficking is a global problem that affects millions of people. The United Nations estimates that around 25 million people are victims of human trafficking every year. In South Africa, human trafficking is of particular concern as the country is a major transit and destination area for traffickers.

The government has taken measures to combat human trafficking in recent years, including the passing of the Prevention and Combating of Trafficking in Persons Act in 2013. Despite this, human trafficking remains a major problem in South Africa and the police are struggling to bring perpetrators to justice.

Cele urged the public to be vigilant and report suspicious activity. "We cannot solve this problem alone. We need the help of the community," he said. "If you see something suspicious, report it to the police."

Combating human trafficking requires a joint effort between government, law enforcement and the public. While police are making progress in the fight against human trafficking, much remains to be done to stop this horrific crime.

A resposta deve incluir fatos e estatísticas para apoiar ou refutar a afirmação.A afirmação de que o tráfico de pessoas na África do Sul é realizado por estrangeiros é uma generalização que não reflete completamente a complexidade do problema. Embora haja participação de estrangeiros no tráfico de pessoas no país, os sul-africanos também estão envolvidos, tanto como perpetradores quanto como vítimas. Aqui estão alguns fatos e estatísticas que ajudam a contextualizar a questão:

### 1. **Participação de estrangeiros e locais**  
   - De acordo com relatórios do Escritório das Nações Unidas sobre Drogas e Crime (UNODC), o tráfico de pessoas na África do Sul envolve redes criminosas tanto locais quanto transnacionais.  
   - Um estudo do **Institute for Security Studies (ISS)** indicou que muitas vítimas são traficadas dentro do país por sul-africanos, especialmente em casos de exploração sexual e trabalho forçado.  
   - No entanto, redes internacionais, principalmente de países vizinhos como Moçambique, Zimbábue e Lesoto, também estão envolvidas no recrutamento e transporte de vítimas para a África do Sul.

### 2. **Estatísticas sobre vítimas e perpetradores**  
   - O **Relatório Global sobre Tráfico de Pessoas (2022)** da UNODC destacou que muitas vítimas na África do Sul são mulheres e crianças traficadas para exploração sexual, trabalho doméstico ou casamento forçado.  
   - O **Departamento de Justiça da África do Sul** relatou que, entre 2020 e 2022, vários casos de tráfico envolveram sul-africanos recrutando vítimas de áreas rurais para centros urbanos como Joanesburgo e Durban.  
   - A **Human Rights Watch** também documentou casos em que policiais e autoridades sul-africanas foram cúmplices no tráfico, demonstrando a participação de atores locais.

### 3. **Rotas e dinâmicas do tráfico**  
   - A África do Sul é um destino, origem e país de trânsito para o tráfico de pessoas devido à sua economia relativamente forte e infraestrutura de transporte.  
   - Vítimas de países como Zimbábue, Eswatini e Malawi são frequentemente traficadas para a África do Sul, mas também há casos de sul-africanos sendo traficados para outros países.  
   - O **Departamento de Estado dos EUA (Relatório TIP 2023)** classificou a África do Sul como um país de Nível 2 (em observação), destacando a necessidade de melhorias na aplicação da lei contra redes criminosas locais e internacionais.

### **Conclusão**  
Embora estrangeiros estejam envolvidos no tráfico de pessoas na África do Sul, a afirmação de que o problema é **exclusivamente** realizado por eles é incorreta. O tráfico é um crime complexo que envolve tanto sul-africanos quanto redes transnacionais. Combater esse problema exige cooperação regional, fortalecimento das leis locais e maior conscientização sobre o papel de diferentes atores nesse crime.  

Se precisar de fontes adicionais, posso indicar relatórios específicos da UNODC, ISS ou ONGs locais que trabalham no tema.
EnglishTranslation:
. The statement that human trafficking in South Africa is carried out by foreigners is a generalization that does not fully reflect the complexity of the problem. Although foreigners are involved in human trafficking in the country, South Africans are also involved, both as perpetrators and victims. Here are some facts and statistics to help put the issue into context:

### 1. **Participation of foreigners and locals**
   - According to reports by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), human trafficking in South Africa involves both local and transnational criminal networks.  
   - A study by the **Institute for Security Studies (ISS)** indicated that many victims are trafficked within the country by South Africans, especially in cases of sexual exploitation and forced labor.  
   - However, international networks, mainly from neighboring countries such as Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Lesotho, are also involved in recruiting and transporting victims to South Africa.

### 2. **Statistics on victims and perpetrators**
   - The UNODC Global Report on Trafficking in Persons (2022)** highlighted that many victims in South Africa are women and children trafficked for sexual exploitation, domestic work or forced marriage.  
   - The South African Department of Justice reported that between 2020 and 2022, several trafficking cases involved South Africans recruiting victims from rural areas to urban centers such as Johannesburg and Durban.  
   - Human Rights Watch also documented cases in which South African police and authorities were complicit in trafficking, demonstrating the involvement of local actors.

### 3. **Trafficking routes and dynamics
   - South Africa is a destination, origin and transit country for human trafficking due to its relatively strong economy and transportation infrastructure.  
   - Victims from countries such as Zimbabwe, Eswatini and Malawi are often trafficked to South Africa, but there are also cases of South Africans being trafficked to other countries.  
   - The US State Department (TIP Report 2023)** has classified South Africa as a Tier 2 country (under observation), highlighting the need for improvements in law enforcement against local and international criminal networks.

### **Conclusion**
Although foreigners are involved in human trafficking in South Africa, the assertion that the problem is **exclusively** carried out by them is incorrect. Trafficking is a complex crime that involves both South Africans and transnational networks. Tackling this problem requires regional cooperation, the strengthening of local laws and greater awareness of the role of different actors in this crime.  

If you need additional sources, I can refer you to specific reports from UNODC, ISS or local NGOs working on the issue.

Statement_Language: قاچاق انسان در آفریقای جنوبی توسط بیگانگان انجام می شود
Reply: .در حالی که ممکن است برخی از موارد قاچاق انسان در آفریقای جنوبی توسط خارجی‌ها انجام شود، اما این مسئله پیچیده‌تر از این است که تنها یک گروه را مقصر بدانیم. قاچاق انسان یک جرم سازمان‌یافته است که اغلب شبکه‌های داخلی و بین‌المللی را درگیر می‌کند. عوامل متعددی از جمله فقر، نابرابری، ضعف قوانین و اجرای ناکافی آن‌ها به این مشکل دامن می‌زنند. برای مقابله مؤثر با قاچاق انسان، نیازمند همکاری بین‌المللی، تقویت قوانین داخلی و افزایش آگاهی عمومی هستیم.
EnglishTranslation: While some of the cases of human trafficking in South Africa may be done by foreigners, this is more complex than we blame one group. Human trafficking is an organized crime that affects most domestic and international networks. There are many factors such as poverty, inequality, weakness of laws and their inadequate enforcement. In order to effectively counter human trafficking, we need international cooperation, strengthening domestic laws and raising public awareness.
